conclusion: When studying the structure of atomic nuclei, it is necessary to bombard the nuclei with particles of very high energy. To enable charged particles to attain such high energies, scientists have invented various types of particle accelerators.

Figure 1 shows a schematic diagram of an accelerating device, which consists of multiple metal cylinders with the same cross-sectional area arranged in sequence, with their axes aligned on the same straight line.
The cylinders with odd numbers are connected to one pole of an alternating current (AC) power supply, while those with even numbers are connected to the other pole.
The variation pattern of the potential difference between the two poles of the AC power supply is shown in Figure 2.
At t = 0, the potential difference between the odd-numbered cylinders and the even-numbered cylinders is positive.
At this moment, an electron is located at the center of a metal plate (numbered 0) connected to the even-numbered cylinders.
The electron starts from rest and is accelerated by the electric field between the plate and cylinder 1, entering cylinder 1 along the central axis.
To ensure that the electron is accelerated in the gaps between the cylinders, the lengths of the cylinders must be designed according to a specific rule.

The gravitational force and relativistic effects on the electron are neglected.
